Are the offspring of an American-born citizen and a prince from a foreign country eligible to run for president? A viral Facebook post says yes.
"So. Harry and Megan's children are eligible to be POTUS," the Feb. 24 post states. "Way to play the long game, George III."
King George III ruled the British Empire during the American Revolution from 1763-83, according to the Library of Congress.
In an ironic twist, George's descendant Prince Harry married an American, actress and divorcee Meghan Markle, hence the "long game" referenced in the Facebook post.
The post is an exact copy of a Feb. 23 post to Facebook group Formidable Republican Opposition.

"I found the meme somewhere else, but I don't recall exactly where — I believe a friend posted it, but I don't know if it was original content from them. The meme obviously doesn't contain the nuance of the actual situation, but it's funny," the poster, Dillion Beyer, told USA TODAY in an email.

Harry and Meghan — also known as the Duke and Duchess of Sussex — captured international attention after a bombshell interview with media mogul Oprah Winfrey aired on March 7 that included, among other claims, accusations of racism against members of the royal family. The Facebook post predates the interview.
The duchess announced her second pregnancy in February, according to USA TODAY. A son, Archie Harrison Mountbatten-Windsor, was born in 2019.
Time will tell if the youngest members of the Sussex family will decide to run for president some day, but there may be a few obstacles in their way.

Article II, Section 1 of the Constitution states "no Person except a Natural Born Citizen, or a Citizen of the United States, at the time of the Adoption of this Constitution, shall be eligible to the Office of President." The candidates must also be at least 35 years old and have resided in the country for 14 or more years, according to the Constitution Annotated.

"Children born of Prince Harry and Megan Markle in the United States would be citizens and would be eligible to run for president when they are old enough, but they would have to win this in an election rather than inherit the office," John R. Vile, professor of political science at Middle TennesseeState University, told USA TODAY.

USA TODAY reported on the Sussexes' move to the United States over a year ago. The couple's newborn would face no barriers to running for the highest office in the land. But Archie was born in the United Kingdom and would have been ineligible to run a few decades ago.

Standards for naturalization were first outlined in H.R. 40, or the 1790 Naturalization Act. Children born abroad to U.S. citizens were automatically granted citizenship under the act, but it also limited access to citizenship primarily to immigrants from Western Europe.

The statute was altered by Congress in 1855 so U.S. citizenship for children born abroad depended upon the citizenship of the fathers at the time of birth. The contingency was null if the father never lived in the United States, according to a 2016 Fordham Law Review article.

Fortunately for some well-known presidential candidates, such as Canadian-born Sen. Ted Cruz and the late Sen. John McCain, who was born in Panama, the statute changed in 1978 to recognize citizenship to children born abroad if either parent was a U.S. citizen at birth, according to U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services. (The Senate also passed a resolution in 2008 recognizing McCain as a natural-born citizen.)

USCIS also lists a specific category for children of a U.S. citizen and an alien Under this condition, the child can acquire citizenship at birth if  the citizen parent lived physically in the United States for at least five years with two of those years occurring after 14 years of age. Archie Mountbatten-Windsor appears to tick all the boxes.

But Harry and Meghan's children will face another barrier: Archie is seventh in the line of succession for the British throne, according to an official website for the Royal Family. His future sibling will also inherit a position in line. This presents a conflict of interest under the Foreign Emoluments Clause.

The clause states that "(N)o Person holding any Office of Profit or Trust under them (i.e., the United States), shall, without the Consent of the Congress, accept of any present, Emolument, Office, or Title, of any kind whatever, from any King, Prince, or foreign State," according to the Constitution Center. The Sussex siblings would either have to renounce their claims to a seat of foreign power or seek a special exemption from Congress.
Vile told USA TODAY the Founding Fathers dismissed possible rule from a foreign head of state when the Constitution was being written.

"When the U.S. Constitutional Convention met in Philadelphia in 1787, the delegates actually posted a story saying that they could not say how they were deliberating, but they could assure the people that they were not (contrary to some rumors of the time) considering a foreign-born prince," he wrote in an email.

We rate this claim MISSING CONTEXT, based on our research. A Facebook post stating the children of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle will some day be eligible to run for president misses a key detail. The children would have to renounce their claims to the British throne or seek special permission from Congress under the Foreign Emoluments Clause before being permitted to run.
